instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMCâ€™s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message:
Hi there amigos
I have a 00165 here with what I thought was going to be a basic no green light repair but it's turning into a rabbit hole. There was corrosion around SMC, no much. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is low at 8.16v PP3v42 is actually just consistently 3.41. 
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is on 3V
Have replaced SMC. same issue. I looked around j9500 and all looks good, reinforced the solder joints on it just in case. 
Have also replaced <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message:
You should get correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> without LIO flex connected; even no Magsafe light in such case.

Post voltage and diode mode to ground at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.
Check components and traces continuity around SMC.
Is <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message:
Oh I see, that's good to know. 
both lines are 0.5 in diode and 3.41 in voltage
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> is 3.3 yep 

All around the SMC is checking out OK, I've specifically also replaced <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> because it looked a little toasty, but it did measure fine even before

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message:
Post diode mode readings with 3 decimals; less than 1% difference is allowed.

Do you get 12MHz oscillation at Y5110?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message:
diode for both is 0.499

I don't have an oscilloscope so I just straight up replaced Y5110 but have the same result

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message: is it possible at all that both SMC's are actually faulty in the exact same way?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message:
Post DC voltages of Y5110.
Working one gets 1-1.2V DC normally...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message: Hmmm strange. pin 1 of Y5110 is getting 1.7V every other pin is getting 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message:
think we're getting closer, there was a line break which I couldn't see between <SIGNAL>SMC_XTAL</SIGNAL> test port and <RESISTOR>R5110</RESISTOR>/Y5110
Ran jumper, still same issues but im now getting 1.1V on pin 3 of Y5110 which i guess is good news

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message:
Still incorrect <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (F7140) voltage?
Check it without battery, nor LIO flex connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message: yup still 8.18v on f7140 both sides. No flex connected

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message:
Do you now get 1-1.2V on both <SIGNAL>SMC_E</SIGNAL>/XTAL lines?

Try known good working SMC.
Once removed, assure to have good traces under it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message:
I get 1.6V on <SIGNAL>SMC_EXTAL</SIGNAL> and 1.2 on <SIGNAL>SMC_XTAL_R</SIGNAL>
Does 1.6 seem too high to you?

Ok will try another SMC

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message: Another SMC, no change. I guess this is a no fix

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message: Check voltage and signals for <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> (2 OF 2) at page 37.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message: The only strange thing I've found there is that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL> is 3.415V just like the PP3v42 line. So PP3v42 is not quite 3.42 and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL> is slightly too high. Not sure if im nitpicking here but I always saw the pp3v42 line as an almost perfect 3v42 on other MacBooks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no green light
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL> is slightly too high"
Not at all; it comes directly from <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> (L5001).

If all good there and SCL/SDA lines of battery bus work, then <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (F7140), should reach 8.5V.
If not, only remain <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and SMC as suspects.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> is good.

Does the fan start normal speed, or directly max speed?
